desc.size: Tree, to 12 m tall. Widespreading crown with long, drooping branches.

part.partText: dull green or brown, smooth, brittle at base.

alternate, with pinkish, 5 - 12 mm long leafstalks; lustrous dark green above, bluish green beneath, 8 - 15 cm long, lanceolate to narrow-lanceolate, tip long-pointed, margins blunt toothed, thick, smooth.
in 2 - 3 cm long, cylindrical catkins; stamens 2, anthers yellow, filaments hairy at base; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; brown, flask-shaped; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: The characteristics of Salix x pendulina are intermediate between its parents. Also see other weeping willow hybrids: S. x rubens, S. x sepulcralis.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: May escape from cultivation and grow near streams, lakes, ponds, and other moist to wet areas.

notes.comments: Salix x pendulina is a hybrid of weeping willow between S. babylonica and S. fragilis. Many cultivated forms of weeping willow are derived from species and hybrids that originated in Europe and Asia. The ancestry and taxonomy is complex—for a discussion see Santamour & McArdle (1988): Cultivars of Salix babylonica and other weeping willows. J. Arboriculture 14:180-184.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow.
